Posts.Content: I haven’t posted in four weeks and would like to say that this forum has helped immeasurably. I have not encountered anything that was not covered either in this forum or by my doctors’ forecasts. I strongly encourage all who are facing even the possibility of PC to start with this forum, read everything you can (and judicially investigate/consider the source), and do not be afraid to ask questions of your doctor. Yesterday I finished week 5 of EBRT/IMRT – 24 “doses” down, 15 to go. My chronology is in my signature, with one exception – due to the standard urination problem (frequency, occasional difficulty starting stream, occasional cases of unable to maintain stream) I was experiencing before treatment, my urologist prescribed Uroxatral to alleviate additional issues during treatment. I think it has been a big help. I still have frequency and occasional (but at least not chronic) issues, but so far have not had pain or leakage. I must say I feel very fortunate, compared to some of the other cases shared in this forum. I would characterize side effects (hot flashes, fatigue, a couple of instances of dizziness) as annoying but manageable. The worst thing is making sure to have a full bladder for the daily treatments – as others on this forum have said, I’ve come to REALLY appreciate my two-day weekend breaks. Hot flashes were less than minor the first few weeks, but due to the cumulative effects of the treatments, they have become much more intense in the past week. Still, I would say manageable, because I have observed definite connections to caffeine intake, an occasional glass of wine, and large meals – things I can control with a bit of discipline! After each Wednesday treatment I see the oncologist for a “how goes it” session. He asks questions about my experience and wellbeing and makes recommendations for treatment management and activities. This coming week I’m scheduled for an ultrasound with my urologist, fingers are crossed for a good result on that.
Posts.Signature: Age at diagnosis: 70 9/14/15  Annual Physical with GP, PSA 6.58. 2016  no PSA ordered prior to annual physical. 12/11/17  Annual Physical with GP, PSA 37.34; GP ordered 30 days on Ciprofloxacin to eliminate bacterial as cause. 1/17/18  Follow up with GP, PSA 34.48. GP ordered referral to urologist. 1/18/18  Urorologist performed DRE, found a knot (his word). 1/23/18  Biopsy. 2/06/18  FU with urologist for biopsy results. Gleason 7 (4+3), 12 samples: five samples at Gleason 7 (4+3); two at Gleason 6 (3+3); two High Grade PIN; three benign. Urologist ordered CT and bone scans. 2/09/18  CT and bone scans, both negative for spreading. 2/23/18  FU with urologist to determine treatment plan. Ruled out surgery, referred to radiology oncologist. 3/12/18  Oncologist performed DRE and discussed treatment options. 3/13/18  hormone injection. 4/17/18  Commenced EBRT, one of 39 treatments
Posts.Title: 24 down, 15 to go

Posts.Content: Thanks for the encouragement, fl drifter. I have an appointment with the urologist Wednesday for "Ultrasound with Post-Void Residual". Not sure what to expect there, but will post results for others to consider. Regards, Jim

Posts.Title: 24 down, 15 to go

Posts.Content: Thanks MichiganMan16. You might get a kick out of this little episode … I like having the first treatment of the day (07:30), figuring that reduces the chance of any delays from backups. So I was sitting there this morning by 07:15 with my full bladder ready for action. The radiologist was a few minutes late (not more than 5, no big deal) calling me in, so I got up onto the table into my mold, they did the alignment, all set and ready to go; however, my picture/personals were not on the monitor, so I wondered about that. Got the scan completed, and I started my mental count for the procedure; got up to three minutes, and wondered why the machine wasn't starting the treatment. Another minute, then another, heard the heavy door, and the radiologist came it to tell me they had a "software glitch" and were downloading software, and treatment would start in "one minute". So I counted off another four, then from the corner of my eye saw the monitors display my file, and the panels began the treatment. Now, while this is all going on, of course, the only thing I could think of was how badly I had to go, which of course only made the sensation even worse! All told, I was "on the table" an extra eight minutes this morning, which at any other time is nothing, but when you're wondering how long you can hold, it seemed interminable!

Posts.Title: 24 down, 15 to go

Posts.Content: Thanks garyi … you and Michael F make it sound like I've been handed off from tactical to approach for the return to home plate, and indeed that's an encouraging way to look at it. On glidepath, on course, looking forward to field in sight and touchdown in two and a half weeks! As I wrote earlier, this forum has helped tremendously to keep surprises out of the picture. Along with all the clinical documentation, before I started RT I read several strings from FBs, and they have helped me anticipate anything I've encountered thus far. I'm just hoping the things I describe might help someone just getting started on the same path to maintain confidence and persevere.

Posts.Title: 24 down, 15 to go

Posts.Content: I've been reading and following the forum for a couple of months. Impressed by the information sharing and support I've seen. A little nervous, but here goes my story ... the chronology is below. After the diagnosis and planning, I began hormone therapy on 3/13/18 in preparation for EBRT. I had my first of 39 EBRT treatments yesterday (4/17). My urologist and oncologist are tremendous, giving me and excellent prognosis, and I have full confidence in both. I'm open to any questions about my case thus far, and willing to share all my diagnosis and treatment experiences.

Posts.Title: First step of the journey

Posts.Content: Thanks for the encouragement, RobLee. Yes, I did read the EBRT and HT sticky entries, those are great reference tools. Agree on the reluctance to diagnose based on PSA alone; GP originally said he had seen PSAs as high as 80 that were not cancer, and ordered the Cipro. Fortunately, though, he did refer me to the urologist for more aggressive exam and screening, so in the long run he did the right thing. I'm just grateful that it is slow-moving, and we caught it early enough for the optimistic prognosis.

Posts.Title: First step of the journey

Posts.Content: Thanks for the welcome, guys. After reading several of the forum posts, gaining a better idea of what to post to help other FBs. Just into fifth week after receiving the HT injection (Eligard). Pain after the injection was slight, very manageable, just felt like a little bruise. First morning after the injection felt very groggy, confused, and tired. Caveat - had picked up my wife from airport late the previous night, so the "hangover" effect could be attributed to insufficient sleep, also possibly an overactive imagination from all the reading leading up to the Eligard. Next few weeks were so-so. Some very infrequent flashes, but nothing causing sweating. I would sense a sort of warmth spreading through my body, nothing lasting longer than 30 seconds. I had been having frequent nighttime urination for several months, so did not notice any increase from the HT. Had a couple of times that I could not get back to sleep, just felt "uncomfortable" and wide-awake. Other than that, I have noticed that I fatigue a bit more frequently during yard work and other exertion, so have learned to pace my activities throughout the day. Have not yet noticed any weight gain; in fact, I seem to have lost 3 pounds since starting HT - but that could be attributed to paying more attention to eating smarter, and reducing alcohol. Still enjoy a glass of wine while reading in the evenings. Today is Thursday, just started EBRT/IMRT on Tuesday, so will withhold observations until I have a comparison. Hope this helps others just starting their journey.

Posts.Title: First step of the journey

Posts.Content: You've taken a very important step - signing on to this forum. Not only is the wealth of information pure gold, but the sharing of experiences will help you feel less isolated and more confident. Do not hesitate to ask your doctors any question you can ever imagine; if one shows any hesitation or impatience at all with you, then move on to someone who will listen. The value of the information and experiences will help you make the treatment decision only you can make. Good luck, there are a lot of us cheering for you.

Posts.Title: Newbie

Posts.Content: DjinTonic, Thanks for the tipoff to the studies. Finally got around to checking them out. I just completed week 5 of treatment (24 of 39 "doses" done). For no good reason, I have been putting off returning to my fitness center workouts since the biopsy came back malignant. I think it has been a case of fearing that something physiologically negative might happen - with no good reason, obviously. I've been rationalizing by using two exercise walks a day with my dog and light yard work. Based on the encouragement from the studies, I will make a focused attempt to get back to the treadmill and light weight resistance at my fitness center (I'm paying for membership, after all!). Again, thanks for the suggestions. Regards, Jim
